page.title: 05Place Names/Guyzance Area.
page.content: The place names in this area can be traced back to the Angle and Norman invasions.The Angles crossed the North Sea and settled along the River Coquet.They cleared the forests, cultivated the land and kept animals. The names of these settlements are stil reflected in farm names today.Brotheraick derives from"Brodor's wic"_a farm belonging to Brodor;Morwick was a farm in a fen and Brainshaugh is corruption of "Bregwines's haugh".A haugh is an area of flat land next to a river.Guyzance dates from the Norman Conquest.Guines was a village near Calais.The first lord of Alnwick after the conquest, Gisbert Tison,gave "Gisyng" to his son,Richard Tison.He then gave the chapel of "Gysyns" to a community of nuns from Alnwick.
